newsitem.title: USA: HEL deals to dominate U.S. ABS issuance this week.
newsitem.headline: HEL deals to dominate U.S. ABS issuance this week.

text.p: Asset-backed securities (ABS) issuance is expected to fall off this week from last week's hectic pace and the deals that will come to market will involve home equity loan-backed securities, experts said.

This week, market players expect an $800 million home equity loan ABS from Advanta, a $270 million home equity line of credit-backed (HELOC) security from GMAC and a $575 million HELOC from IMC. Green Tree, too, is expected to bring a $300 million to $400 million HEL-backed offering.
About $6.5 billion in new issues came to market last week, putting the market ahead of last year's year-to-date total, said Dan Castro, asset-backed analyst at Merrill Lynch & Co.
According to Castro, last year's year-to-date level for total ABS issuance was $84.6 billion. This year's level was $85.1 billion, he added.
Much of last week's issuance was credit card-backed paper, said Castro.
"Over $4.0 billion was fixed rate credit card issuance," he said.
The opportunity to issue asset-backed securities pooling credit card receivables at a low cost prompted several issuers to bring their offerings to market last week.
Deals that came to market last week included transactions from First USA, MBNA, and Chase among others.
The arbitrage available to issuers utilizing the swap market drove fixed rate issuance, said Tom Heidenrich, an asset-backed analyst at BancAmerica Securities Inc.
"You may see one or two more opportunistic issuers taking advantage of the swap spread," he said.
Merrill Lynch's Castro agreed: "The arb is so compelling that issuers are jumping at it."
Wider swap spreads allow credit card issuers to achieve a lower cost of funding by swapping floating rate receivables into fixed rate.

"A credit card issuer's funding is in LIBOR, so they need everything on a floating rate basis," a New York ABS trader said, referring to the London Interbank Offered Rate. Normally, he added, many of these issuers would bring to market a floating rate bond.
Because of last week's hectic pace of fixed rate credit card issuance, fixed-rate credit card ABS spreads to Treasuries Monday morning were one to two basis points wider, according to market players.
The chop and change in Treasury prices in recent weeks has not gone unnoticed by asset-backed market players.
"The see-sawing (in prices) may have left some investors a little skittish," said Heidenrich.
While there has been a flurry of fixed-rate product from credit card issuers, at least one participant will bring to market a floating-rate ABS transaction this week.
Market players said Discover will bring to market a $500 million floating rate credit card ABS deal lead managed by Morgan Stanley, Chase, Bank of America, and First Chicago.

A New York trader said price talk on the offering, a $500 million five-year floater, was eight to 10 basis points over LIBOR. A $26 million B piece on the offering was expected to price at 28 basis points over one-month LIBOR.
Issuance this week may be off from last week, but participants expected new issues business to pick up in September.
"In September, the flood gates will open. There will $24 to $25 billion in new issues in September," said Castro.

Participants said that, while secondary market activity has been subdued in the last week -- most buysider focus has been on the fresh paper in the primary mart -- the coming two weeks may see secondary activity among dealers.

This week and next week may see heightened inter-dealer activity because some dealers were "squaring their books" -- that is, cleaning up balance sheets to reduce their inventory of bonds at quarter's end, according to a New York trader.
"Everybody will be watching to see what dealers do with their inventories. They will watch for how aggressively they bring them to market," the New York ABS trader said.
(( -- U.S. Mortgage Unit, 212-859-1668 ))
